thread.title: Katina Powell: Exposing UofL sex scandal was about the money
thread.title_full: Katina Powell: Exposing UofL sex scandal was about the money

author: courier-journal.com
title: Katina Powell: Exposing UofL sex scandal was about the money
text:
In an interview with Katina Powell on ABC's "The View" on Friday, the self-described "escort queen" says "it's about the book and the money" for why she exposed the alleged University of Louisville basketball sex scandal.
She also said she called the NCAA to tell her story, but the NCAA "did nothing about it" regarding sex parties for players and recruits.
Powell appeared on the ABC talk show “The View” at 11 a.m. Friday to discuss her allegations that she was paid by a former member of the University of Louisville basketball staff to provide escorts to strip for players and recruits.
Some of the escorts, including two of her daughters, say they also had sex with the athletes.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Coach confirms Andre McGee resigns from UMKC
In her book, “Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen,” Powell alleges she was paid thousands of dollars and given game tickets by former U of L director of basketball operations Andre McGee. McGee’s attorney, Scott C. Cox, said McGee knew Powell but never paid for escorts to have sex with players or recruits.
Investigations of the allegations are ongoing by the NCAA and state prosecutors.
Powell wrote that her own daughters were among the escorts. She has since said they were not minors at the time and that she didn’t personally profit.
According to an ESPN report released this week, five former U of L players or recruits backed up Powell’s account of parties with strippers, while one former recruit confirmed he had sex with one of the women.
McGee resigned Friday morning as assistant basketball coach at the University of Missouri-Kansas City.
McGee had been placed on administrative leave at UMKC after the publication Powell’s book.
McGee, who has not publicly responded to Powell’s claims, said in an email to the athletic director of the Kansas City school that he had “reluctantly” decided to resign because the team deserves a full-time assistant and he was not able to provide that “while the false allegations against me are investigated.”
Cox declined comment Friday but previously said McGee "has never supplied a prostitute or escort to a player or recruit at the University of Louisville."
